comments.commentBody:
This is long overdue. Public housing tenants have been suffering horribly from second hand smoke and have been requesting smoke free policies for many years.

Landlords have a right to prohibit smoking in their rental housing and many, if not most, do. Smoke free is the norm these days for housing, hotel rooms workplaces and all indoor public places. Smoke free public housing is consistent with these norms.

Possession of cannnabis is already illegal in all federally subsidized public housing and will remain so. When cannabis is legalized in a state it's usually subject to the same restrictions as tobacco. Posssession is legal but smoking is restricted.

I hope that the ban works, but it's going to be hard to enforce. While a lot of those who smoke say that they know it's not good for them, virtually none of them actually understand that the smoke is poisonous for everyone exposed and that the risks of contracting the worst of diseases reflects how many have done so, already. Of every one hundred people who smoke, thirty three will die of respiratory, cardio vascular, or cancer diseases, the only question is which ones. Every smoker doubles their chances of dying due to one of these diseases, every one of them. But what I see everyday are many people of all ages smoking, obviously in the belief that they probably will not suffer because of doing so.

Me being a New York citizen, and passing by those complexes (and venturing in them as my grandmother lives in one), this smoking ban has to go into effect. I suffer from asthma and to deal with other people who choose to voluntarily poison their lungs and poison the lungs of their fellow human beings, it's just disgusting. We can leave cars, alone, they're a mode of transportation and are vital, but smoking is not essential. Even in my apartment I have to fear that the other tenants are smoking in the halls at night. This indeed needs to be addressed.

This seemingly laudable goal makes the poor into slaves of the state. Will we demand they take blood tests to verify they don't secretly smoke in their bathrooms. Will we have inspectors or special smoke detectors to enforce the rules?

America has become a country of infantilized citizens, not just the poor. Everyone expects the State to do something for them, even though it rarely happens without special favors. People expect the cops to protect them from the desperately poor and the homeless, as society crumbles around us. Every stoplight has a beggar, some a beggar at each corner.

All because people have surrendered their autonomy to parasitic financial moguls who have devalued everything.

The Spanish philosopher, Ortega y Gasset, sais that if you several people arguing, the minority is right and the majority is wrong. This is what is happening in this discussion. The opinion of the professor is more valid than the many of the oppressors. Most of their arguments is repetitious, but they go at it with glee. Thy are sure to be so righteous, like religious fervor.
The assertion that smoke from one apartment seeps into another is ridiculous. I happen to be an engineer and can refute it in court anytime.
Let's be honest, this is class warfare. If second hand smoke were problem in apartment buildings, how come smoking is not prohibited in middle class and luxury buildings?
Smoking is bad for the smoker and family; education is the only solution, not repression and denial of rights of the poor.

Excellent, well-meaning rule. Many unsubsidized apartment buildings across the country already have prohibitions against smoking. Even the security deposit clauses state that evidence of smoking will automatically result in seizure of $350 for cleaning, in addition to what is normally a $200 cleaning fee on top of the damage deposit.

Besides, how can anyone living in subsidized apartments actually afford to smoke, drink anything other than water, and make their children sick from smoke pollution?

So many comments supporting the "right" to smoke. As my mother often says, "freedom means we are free to be dumb." We should all be fighting for cleaner air. Those who insist on inhaling chemicals can just suck car exhaust. It's far cheaper and in abundant supply.
Many public housing projects have serious levels of crime, often associated with drug dealing.  If that is relatively uncontrolled, who on earth is going to enforce a smoking ban?

This may be a bit of a preconceived idea.  Have a look at the comment by Ralph Cramden, above.  Keep in mind that the vast majority of people living in public housing facilities do not commit criminal offenses.

If the government gets away with banning smoking in housing for the poor, how long before they try to outlaw cigarettes altogether?  Then we can have bootleg ciggies, just like we had bootleg booze in the 1920s &30s.  Great, I missed the excitement of those glorious days because I wasn't born til 1940.  Now I won't  to watch old James Cagney movies for excitement!

I am a former smoker. I did not smoke in my own home, after having cleaned apartments where I had previously lived and had smoked inside. Smoke heavily damages the interiors of homes. It also ruins furniture, flooring, walls, beds, drapes, books, etc.

In my current home, the previous tenant smoked, and the bathroom walls seep nicotine when they get steamed up.

Blame also the architects and community non profits who built these HUD and city housing buildings with weak ventilation systems. 1960s no bathroom window, 1970s and 80s no bathroom window and no kitchen window. Instead tiny vents. So many of these buildings both private and public have not cleaned their vent air shafts clogged with grease and the horsepower on the roof fans either no longer works adequately or was too weak when built day 1 for the height of the building.  So one smoker's exhaling can be smelled upstairs despite concrete floors since the walls are not insulated and the vents are not checked if they are even working..  If you can hear your neighbors light switch, you know smoke is passing thru and lingers in the shared air. At least  balcony barbecues were banned in NYC only recently.

'We all inhabit this planet, we all breathe the same air, we all cherish our children's future...' Kennedy trying to explain why there was hope that we and the U.S.S.R. might one day be able to get rid of nuclear weapons.

We all breathe the same air and when one pollutes it, others must inhale that pollution. We are separate beings but we share everything that we need to survive in one way or another, whether we consider how what we might do affects others or not.

Well said.
I understand the concerns of health damage from second hand smoke. I live in a pre-war rent stabilized building in a decent neighborhood. The construction and proper maintenance mean that my neighbors smoking does not seep into my apartment. I am neither rich nor poor. Just lucky to have a job that allows me to afford good basics for living.
Perhaps HUD should invest in revitalizing and maintaining the decrepit buildings they are allowing citizens to live in. Perhaps invest in security for these citizens as crime is a much greater health risk than second hand smoke.
This is big brother demonizing and controlling the poorest of the population.

Whose freedoms will they come for next? I second that question.

Another law that can't be consistently enforced, whose enforcement will be discriminatory and politicized, and which will be flagrantly ignored.

Unless you are willing to evict people and make them homeless for feeding their addictions, don't pass stupid rules like this.

Cigarette smoke is equally poisonous to all and every cigarette poisons the smoker and those around similarly. It stands to reason that the experience of having to quit brings the same kinds of physical responses to everyone. The difference in how one person manages to overcome the initial withdrawal symptoms and to refrain from starting to smoke again until the cravings diminish to zero, seems to be where the differences are to be found. I quit a very heavy habit long ago. It was a big challenge but it did not involve the suffering that alcoholics and drug addicts experience when they try to quit cold turkey. The challenge was not with the symptoms from the withdraw nor with the strength of the cravings but with the ease of resuming the habit and of knowing that temporarily quitting was never difficult -- it was with willingly never having any desire to ever smoke, again.

Cigarettes are legal products. This is a cruel attack on the rights of the poor. The rich republicans can use all the tobacco they want in their mansions, but no rights for the poor. Shame on the republicans.
The Democrats are making these rules.  They know better on how you should live.  As Ms. Pelosi once admonished, embrace the suck.

Fred: this is being done by a Democratic administration, under the auspices of a Democratic head of HUD. In fact, the majority (not all, just most) bans and regressive taxes on smoking have been instituted by Democrats. On the other hand, why are you assuming that only Republicans (and rich ones at that) smoke?

I'd be on board with this policy provided they also make some buildings available to smokers who try to quit but fail to do so. Giving up ANY addiction is really hard, and smoking is a legal habit. It seems cruel not to have any fallback available for those who really can't quit, or who are made completely miserable by the process.

Yes, even in public housing. (Why should only the wealthy be allowed to have vices? It's miserable enough to be poor.)
They can smoke outside.  Every market rate apartment complex in my city bans smoking.  I see some of my fellow residents smoking outside everytime I leave the building.

Cigarettes were, not so long ago, pitched as healthy. ("It's toasted!") Many people became addicted. Cigarettes were big business and media collected $$$ promoting different brands and encouraging new users.

We know the costs now, but smokers didn't set out to become addicted or to endanger others. Those I know try to restrict their smoking to their vehicle, or to a particular room. (Most city folk don't have vehicles, so that leaves only the second option.) They're doing the best they can with an addiction and a habit of consumption that was actively promoted.

We should discourage smoking by all reasonable means. Telling someone addicted to nicotine they they cannot smoke anywhere in their home is not reasonable.

Not that anyone will notice this comment.

Many many public housing authorities have successfully implemented a non-smoking ban. The article is correct that program particpants want this. Program participants call out their neighbors who cheat.

Biggest problem are elders. Biggest reason why elders who smoke stop smoking in their unit -- new articles about an elder burning to death while smoking in bed. Same reason why some elderly residetns are so harsh on their peers -- not wanting to be put out on the street from a fire.

Elderly poor do not so much care about second hand smoke as they care about not becoming homeless; Odd thing that; people who live in low income housing are afraid of having no housing.
I certainly noticed your comment.  It refreshing to get a bit of detail on the matter rather than the endless ideology.  Much appreciated.

I've lived next door to individuals who smoke, and the smoke can come into my home as if the smoker was in my home. It's a helpless and crazy-making feeling to smell the neighbor's cigarette smoke in your child's room. Maybe the non-smokers would have difficulties moving to another home as well. What makes me uncomfortable about the new rule is that it is income-based. We have lots of sensible rules to keep us safe - how fast you can drive on the highway, that you need to get a permit and inspection for building projects, no burn days, certain things don't go down the kitchen drain, etc., but they are for all of us and not selective by income and circumstance.

amazingly intrusive and amazing the article skirts the issues.  as if the government has any right to tell me how i have to behave in my home.  if i have a cigarette after a great meal or sex, or if helps me to lose weight - the challenges inherent in living with others is part and parcel to living with others, it shouldn't be eliminated because some agency makes a strong case for its values.  soon a plumber will have to report an ashtray, and later they'll be reporting a wine glass, and later they'll be reporting a volume of the quran, new testiment, and soon enough a copy of the NYT.

I fully expect legal challenges to this policy which, in focusing on urban public housing, disproportionately affects minorities. Our national obsession with race, abetted by the Times, will eviscerate this attempt at sanity.

How about instead of taking poor folks cigarettes and tobacco we actually provide help so they won't be so freakin' stressed out that they use cigarette for a cheap chill. No that would be too much like decency. Instead let's just take their freakin' cigarettes away from so the rest of us don't have to deal with the the second hand smoke from their attempts to medicate themselves. But of course.
Stressed?  Most of these people don't work, have food stamps, and have everything provided for them.  I know, I work with them.

Tara, you don't think it's stressful to have to apply for food stamps & other low cost alternatives to normal living?  And, when you have to apply to a woman as unsympathetic as you clearly are can certainly make a person need to buy a pack of cigarettes & a bottle of wine & sit in a corner with them  for a while.

I can see people complaining that we have no right to tell welfare recipients how to live. We are picking on the poor. However, many children living in public housing suffer from asthma and other respiratory problems. It is prudent to make non-smoking the norm inside buildings. It will make it healthier for everyone.
Unfortunately, it is impossible to keep illegal drugs out of the buildings let alone a deadly legal one. Without actually throwing people out in the street, along with their innocent children, there is no punishment that can work. I don't see how this can be enforced when welfare recipients complain about not having enough money but manage to always have enough to buy cigarettes. Cutting off benefits only harms the kids. I'm sure someone would bring a lawsuit if those in public housing were forced to enter a smoking cessation program to be allowed to keep their benefits. It's worth a try.

It's not "hate" and "righteousness." Smoking is dangerous to other people around you, always, all the time, 100% of the time. There is no not harmful exposure to tobacco smoke for other people.

It's not like alcohol which is only dangerous to self or others in situations when it is seriously *abused.* The majority of people who drink do not abuse it. The majority of people who drink alcohol do not do it in a way which damages their health or endangers others.

Every single person who smokes is doing something that severely damages their health and the health of those around them, all the time.

Considering the damage secondhand smoke can do to the health of innocent bystanders, especially to children, babies, pregnant women, and the elderly, there is nothing "radical" about the public asking that our environment be smoke free.

The difference between alcohol consumption and smoking is apples and oranges.

and Elke
Finally got around to doing yesterday's puzzle; so, naturally thought that we had more of the "I" theme today. To wit: I RON, ,I ROBOT, I MAC, I DAHO and I NTERLAKEN. The latter is the gateway to Grindelwald , which when SNOWY has great skiing, and when not, great climbing/hiking. The Jungfraubahn will take you through the Eiger, and it stops at a window in the North face for a great lookout over the valley.
Re the BEAN theme: the Swiss have a saying that " each bean , a note " ("jedes Bohnle ,ein Tonle " ).
Better to stick with raclette- melted cheese and POTATO and small pickles. And hot chocolate.
